Astronomy is the study of the universe and everything in it. It is a branch of science that seeks to understand the nature of the cosmos, from the smallest particles to the vast expanse of space itself. Astronomers use a variety of techniques, including observations, experiments, and mathematical models, to learn about the universe. They study the sun, moon, planets, stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects, as well as the forces that shape them, such as gravity and light. By examining the universe in different wavelengths of light, from visible light to radio waves and X-rays, astronomers can gain a deeper understanding of the universe's composition and evolution. This knowledge has led to many important discoveries, including the existence of dark matter and dark energy, which are mysterious substances that make up a large portion of the universe's mass-energy budget. Astronomers use a variety of techniques to collect data, including telescopes, space probes, and computer simulations. One area of study in astronomy is exoplanetary science, which focuses on discovering and characterizing planets outside our solar system. Researchers use a range of methods, including the transit method and the radial velocity method, to detect and study these distant worlds.
